{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3555859,"name":"Kade Dressing","username":"Kade","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/k/c57346/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-03-13T04:16:37.532Z","cooked":"

Hello, me and my team have been using a field centric code for our swerve drive since last year. The only thing that has changed has been the way we call the SPI port. Additionally, this worked perfectly fine for the first portion of this year, as well as during the start of the first competition we competed in in Belton this past weekend. However, after our second match, our gyro mysteriously stopped working. I initially thought it was a hardware issue. I went through steps such as: swapping gyro, and swapping the roborio. Both steps failed. Then, yesterday, I added a print statement into our code that tells us if the gyro is connected, System.out.println(m_gyro.isConnected());. This code printed out “true”. Following this, I tested again, and yet again, nothing changed, it was still broken. We go into competition this Friday at San Antonio, and would love to see our field relativity work again to help us with our autonomous, as well as our driving. If anyone could provide me with some help, that would be greatly appreciated.

Github

Kade:

However, after our second match, our gyro mysteriously stopped working.

How did you determine this, what behavior was the robot exhibiting that brought you to this conclusion?

Without knowing exactly what it was doing, it’s hard to know exactly what may be wrong. I see that the gyroscope is connected, that’s a good sign. Could you maybe add the following lines to your DriveSubsystem.java periodic() method?

SmartDashboard.putNumber("Gyro Angle", m_gyro.getAngle());
SmartDashboard.putNumber("Odometry Angle", m_odometry.getPoseMeters().getRotation().getDegrees());

As the robot rotates, this will hopefully show meaningful (or not) values and give us a better idea on where to look. I used SmartDashboard because you can right click on the box containing the numbers and turn them into graphs, but you can also switch them to system print statements if you would like.

A few questions about the above numbers:

  1. Do they start at 0, or some arbitrary number?
  2. Is their change consistent with the rotation of the chassis and gyro?
  3. Do they do something odd if the number goes (or tries to go) below 0 or above 360?

If the above numbers correspond with what is happening physically, even after the robot rotates multiple times, ignore the rest of this post. If the numbers seem funny, maybe try the following:

I took a look at your code and I didn’t find anything super obvious. The only possible issue I found is that you feed resetPosition() and update() a Rotation2d object that isn’t bound between [0,360) degrees.*
I.e. I wonder if a value of 743 degrees (as an example) is causing problems later in the match.
I would imagine that the method would be smart enough to know what to do with values outside of the unit circle though.

To ensure this isn’t the issue, you may try replacing Rotation2d.fromDegrees(m_gyro.getAngle()), with Rotation2d.fromDegrees(m_gyro.getAngle() % 360), to ensure exiting the unit circle isn’t the issue.

The code I’m refencing is here:

If you get some time, let me know how that goes and I’ll try to provide more help if it doesn’t work.

Best of luck in San Antonio this weekend. My team will be competing there too.

* Technically rotation 2d is based in radians, but I’m using the example of [0, 360) because you call fromDegrees(angle).

Don’t ask me why, but when I added the SmartDashboard.putnumber into the code, it fixed it. I have no clue why. What I have also found funny was that we had issue with drive before, I duplicated the file and it magically worked again.

Thank you for the help! Can’t wait to see you all in competition!
